description.plain:
Alice in Chains are a Seattle-based rock band. They rose to international fame in the early 1990s as part of the ‘grunge’ movement. They are one of the most critically and commercially acclaimed acts of the 90s. Their first 3 studio albums all went multi-platinum and they have received 8 Grammy nominations for Best Hard Rock performance (sadly, never winning once).

Their unique sound comes from the harmonized vocals of co-founders Layne Staley and Jerry Cantrell, as showcased in some of their biggest songs like “No Excuses” from Jar of Flies, “Angry Chair” from Dirt and “Again” from the self-titled album. Cantrell also serves as the primary songwriter and guitarist of the band.

The band was never restricted to grunge. Cantrell believes it to be heavy metal; and indeed a lot of modern heavy metal bands cite Alice in Chains as an influence, including Metallica for Death Magnetic.

The band’s frontman, Layne Staley, suffered throughout his life from depression and substance abuse, which eventually took his life in 2002. It was a huge blow to the industry and many prominent bands recorded songs as odes to Staley.

After extended inactivity, the band recruited William DuVall and have released three successful studio albums since his inclusion.

songs.full_title: Nutshell by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Nutshell

description.plain:
“Nutshell” is a song by Alice in Chains which originally appeared on their 1994 critically acclaimed extended play, Jar of Flies.

Although never released as a single, it is still today one of Alice in Chains' best known songs. The song is notable for its emotional acoustic instrumentation and its electric guitar solo as well as its dark lyrics dealing with loneliness, despair, and death. It is considered a staple of 1990’s alternative rock despite not hitting any single U.S. Billboard chart or any charts around the world. The tempo of this song is 68 bpm.

The song has been covered by numerous bands including Staind who included a live version of “Nutshell” on their greatest hits album. In 2006, Shinedown and Seether covered the song together.

songs.full_title: Rooster by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Rooster

description.plain:
“Rooster” was the fourth single from Dirt. It was the highest-charting from the album in the US, reaching #7 on the rock chart in 1993.

It was written by Alice in Chains guitarist Jerry Cantrell for his father Jerry Cantrell Sr., who went by the nickname “Rooster” while serving with the U.S. Army during the Vietnam War. Jerry Cantrell has stated that his father had the family nickname “Rooster” since childhood due to the way his hair stood up on end as a youth. Some have stated that the song name refers to the 101st airborne and its patch which is the “screaming eagle” and that the Vietnamese, not familiar with a bald eagle, called all members of the 101st ‘roosters’ or ‘chickens’, but Cantrell has never confirmed this.

songs.full_title: Man in the Box by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Man in the Box

description.plain:
Layne Staley said in a now-inaccessible interview that “Man In the Box” is a song is about censorship in the mass media. He also mentioned that he was stoned when he wrote it.

It is one of, if not the, most popular and well-known Alice in Chains songs, despite only peaking at #18 on the Billboard Album Rock Tracks chart.

The track was nominated for the Grammy Award for Best Hard Rock Performance in 1992, but Van Halen’s album, For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge, ended up winning the award. The music video was nominated for the Best Metal/Hard Rock Video, but lost to Aerosmith’s “The Other Side.”

songs.title: Down in a Hole

description.plain:
This song is a love song from guitarist Jerry Cantrell  to the love of his life Courtney Clarke.

Early pressings listed this as the 12th track in the album. Later pressings listed this as the 4th track supposedly to fit better with the band’s desire to have the album loosely tell a story from song to song.

songs.full_title: No Excuses by Alice in Chains
songs.title: No Excuses

description.plain:
‘No Excuses’ is about lead singer Layne Staley’s battle to overcome his heroin addiction. Another theme is Cantrell’s unstable relationship with Layne as well as Cantrell coming to Layne’s aide even if they grow apart. The band became inactive 2 years later when his drug problem became too troublesome. Staley died of a drug overdose in 2002.

No excuses for relapse. Setting a new clean date.

songs.full_title: Them Bones by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Them Bones

description.plain:
In the liner notes of 1999’s Music Bank box set collection, Cantrell said of the song:
“I was just thinking about mortality, that one of these days we’ll end up a pile of bones. It’s a thought for every human being, whether you believe in an after-life or that when we die, that’s it. The thought that all the beautiful things and knowledge and experiences you’ve been through just end when you end scares me, the thought that when you close your eyes for good, it’s gone forever.”

songs.full_title: Sludge Factory by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Sludge Factory

description.plain: This song is about Alice in Chains being forced to complete the album before they were really ready to by Columbia Records. The title itself, “Sludge Factory”, refers to how the label is a factory, pumping out meaningless sludge for no reason other than profit. It also touches on Layne’s struggle with heroin.

songs.full_title: Rotten Apple by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Rotten Apple

description.plain: This song features on the 1994 EP “Jar of Flies,” the first EP to debut on the #1 spot on the Billboard 200. The EP is also the first major studio recording featuring Mike Inez on bass, rather than Mike Starr. It follows the progression of a young person’s developing drug habit and subsequent fall into addiction.

songs.full_title: I Stay Away by Alice in Chains
songs.title: I Stay Away

description.plain:
I Stay Away is the second single from Jar of Flies.

In the liner notes of the Music Bank, Jerry Cantrell said this about the song:

That was the first time we’d written with Mike Inez, which makes this another special song. The whole Jar of Flies EP proved to both us and the fans what a talented and valid part of the band Mike was. He plays the nastiest, darkest shit but he’s got the sweetest heart in the world."

The song is also known for its music video, done completely in claymation by Nick Donkin. The video shows a male teen with a jar of flies at a carnival, in which he releases the flies which cause deadly situations at the carnival.

songs.full_title: Junkhead by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Junkhead

description.plain:
Jerry Cantrell and Layne Staley wrote this. It was their way of expressing their thoughts on drug abuse and how you can’t understand the mind of a drug user unless you are one yourself. Unfortunately, Layne died of a drug overdose.

More specifically, he meant that only an addict could understand another addict; understand the hellish pull that heroin has on a user’s brain.  What sets this commentary apart from most is that it also acknowledges just how fantastic an opiate high really is.

songs.full_title: Heaven Beside You by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Heaven Beside You

description.plain:
“Heaven Beside You” was written primarily by guitarist Jerry Cantrell, who serves as lead vocalist, with Layne Staley providing backing vocals.

It blends the best of the band’s acoustic and metal sides into an aggressively sorrowful contemplation of lost love, as the track is acknowledged by Cantrell to be about a romantic relationship severed by his own infidelity.

songs.full_title: Frogs by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Frogs

description.plain:
The majority of “Frogs” talks about betrayal and loneliness. It also largely discusses addiction and its effects, a common theme throughout the album. This could be attributed to the loneliness stated in the song.

Because of its sludgy sound and dooming lyrics (especially in the outro), Frogs could be argued as Alice in Chains bleakest song.

This is also the longest Alice in Chains song, clocking in at 8 minutes and 18 seconds.

songs.full_title: We Die Young by Alice in Chains
songs.title: We Die Young

description.plain:
This song was written by Jerry after a bus ride to a A.I.C. rehearsal where he witnessed multiple 9-12 year old kids dealing out drugs and carrying multiple cell phones and pagers to help with dealing drugs.

 “We Die Young” symbolizes the progressively younger age people are starting to die at a due to their involvement in drugs, gangs, and crime from youth.

songs.full_title: The One You Know by Alice in Chains
songs.title: The One You Know

description.plain:
“The One You Know” is the lead single and opening track of Alice in Chains’s album Rainier Fog, which was released on August 24, 2018. The single itself was released on May 4, 2018 alongside an official music video.

Vocalist/guitarist Jerry Cantrell said some things about the song in an interview with SiriusXM:

It’s really aggressive, it’s got a super-aggro riff. I was thinking kind of a [David] Bowie when I was writing it a little bit. So, it’s got kind of a metal  “Fame” shuffle to it almost. It’s a good aggro riff, and it’s got the classic Alice In Chains chorus, with a weird kind of trippy middle part.

songs.full_title: Dam That River by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Dam That River

description.plain:
The song has two popular interpretations; one is which Jerry Cantrell and Sean Kinney get into an altercation, and Kinney breaks a coffee table over Cantrell’s head. The song is a metaphor for revenge, with the inability to ‘dam the river’ symbolizing the uncontrolled bleeding from Cantrell’s head.

The second interpretation is the song being a metaphor for the Green River Killer, who was notorious during the mid-80’s to late-90’s.

description.plain: The 11th and final track of Alice in Chains’s 2009 album of the same name. Written by guitarist/vocalist Jerry Cantrell, “Black Gives Way to Blue” is a short yet poignant song dedicated to deceased frontman Layne Staley. It features special musical guest Elton John playing the piano, something that the band never thought they’d be able to have happen.

songs.full_title: Over Now by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Over Now

description.plain:
“Over Now” is notable for being the last track on the last studio LP recorded with frontman Layne Staley before his death on April 5th, 2002 at the age of 34.

Some have said it’s about a failed relationship, while others have concluded that it’s about the band’s impending demise. Since Staley was unable to tour, and Cantrell didn’t want to become a studio band that didn’t tour, this song was their ode to the end of Alice in Chains as everyone knew them at that time.

songs.full_title: Sickman by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Sickman

description.plain:
Like many songs on the album, “Sickman” is written from the perspective of a man in the clutches of depression and drug abuse. This particular song examines the horrific thoughts he experiences and his struggles to not let them overwhelm him.

In the liner notes of the Alice in Chains boxset Music Bank, Cantrell says that this song came together after Staley asked Cantrell to…

“write him the sickest tune, the sickest, darkest, most fucked up and heaviest thing [Cantrell] could write.”

songs.full_title: Again by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Again

description.plain:
Peaking at #8 on Billboard’s Mainstream Rock Tracks chart, “Again” was nominated for the Grammy Award for Best Hard Rock Performance in 1997.

Another of Staley’s heroin hymns, his lyrics are a painful example of his struggles with depression, addiction and loss, reflecting on the isolation of not knowing anyway out.

In October 1996, after Staley’s former fiancée, Demri Lara Parrott, died of a drug overdose, he was placed on a 24-hour suicide watch. After Staley’s death at the age of 34 in April 2002, Mark Lanegan (Screaming Trees, Queens Of The Stone Age) told Rolling Stone:

He never recovered from Demri’s death. After that, I don’t think he wanted to go on.

songs.title_with_featured: Right Turn (Ft. Chris Cornell & Mark Arm)

description.plain:
The artist of “Right Turn” is unofficially listed as ‘Alice Mudgarden’ due to  Chris Cornell from Soundgarden and Mark Arm from Mudhoney making cameos.

This song appears to be about a male and female character who were in a relationship but broke up. It has left both of them in emotional pain. The male character is the first to be hurt by the breakup, then he finds out the woman has also been hurt. They both wonder why exactly the relationship/chemistry between them didn’t work out.

songs.full_title: Sunshine by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Sunshine

description.plain:
Jerry wrote this song as a tribute to his mother Gloria, who passed away in 1987. Alice in Chains had just moved from Seattle to L.A. after the death of their friend Andrew Wood, lead vocalist of Mother Love Bone, and were in the middle of recording their first album, Facelift.

In an interview with Spin Magazine Jerry had this to say:

When I was a little kid, I’d always tell her, “I’ll be famous and buy you a house and you’ll never have to work again. I’ll take care of you like you took care of me.‘ When she passed away, it was a really shitty time for me. I didn’t know how to deal with it then, and I still don’t. But it gave me the impetus to do what I’m doing.

songs.full_title: Your Decision by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Your Decision

description.plain:
The fourth track from Alice in Chains’s 2009 album Black Gives Way to Blue, and the third single from the album. Written by vocalist/guitarist Jerry Cantrell, “Your Decision” is about the choices people make and the consequences that ensue as a result of them. It is unclear who this song specifically targets, though fans theorize that it’s aimed at deceased frontman Layne Staley and/or former bassist Mike Starr (who died two years after this recording due to a prescription drug overdose).

“Your Decision” is different from most songs in the album due to being a slower acoustic ballad that’s lighter in tone than the others, while also being sad yet calm and at peace. It topped the US Hot Rock and Mainstream Rock charts some months after release.

songs.full_title: Rainier Fog by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Rainier Fog

description.plain: The title of this track comes from the Mount Rainier, which overlooks Seattle. It’s actually about the Seattle grunge scene in the early 90’s from which the band launched into stardom, alongside bands like Nirvana, Soundgarden, Pearl Jam, Screaming Trees and Mother Love Bone. The original demo of this track was recorded by Jerry Cantrell and Duff McKagan (from Guns N' Roses, they also toured together throughout 2016) at Cantrell’s house in Los Angeles. McKagan, like Cantrell, is also from the Seattle area.

songs.full_title: Check My Brain by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Check My Brain

description.plain:
“Check My Brain” is the lead single from AIC’s fourth album and was the first official AIC single in ten years. Guitarist Jerry Cantrell wrote it about with irony and sarcasm about his move from Seattle to Los Angeles.

It topped the Rock, Active Rock and Modern Rock Charts – their first to do so on the latter two, and also crossed over to pop, reaching #92 on the Hot 100 in October 2009. It was also a rock chart hit in Canada, and a minor crossover pop hit there as well. “Check” was later nominated for a Best Hard Rock song Grammy.

songs.full_title: Get Born Again by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Get Born Again

description.plain:
Get Born Again is the first track and the first of two new songs on Nothing Safe: The Best of the Box.

The song was originally supposed to appear on Cantrell’s solo album Degradation Trip, but he showed the song to Staley, who wrote lyrics for the song.

Jerry Cantrell:

We tried to work with Dave Jerden again and that didn’t work out for various uncomfortable reasons. We had tracked with him in L.A., and then we went up to Seattle with Toby Wright. So considering it was done in different states with different producers, I think it turned out to be pretty classic Alice.

At the time the band recorded the song, Layne’s heroin addiction was getting the best of him. Jerden stated that Staley was “as white as a ghost” and was very skinny. Cantrell refused to comment on Staley’s condition.

songs.full_title: Died by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Died

description.plain:
The last song Layne Staley ever recorded with Alice in Chains, “Died” describes the agony and devastation he feels about the loss of someone.

It was likely about his ex-fiancée Demri Parrott who introduced Staley to heroin in 1991. After the two had broken up, she died of an infection from a dirty needle in 1996 while shooting heroin.

songs.full_title: Iron Gland by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Iron Gland

description.plain: Iron Gland is probably the most interesting song on Dirt, as in the tracklist on the back of the album, it’s track position (10) doesn’t have a title and is left blank. The album’s sheet music book lists it as “Instrumental”, but it is officially known as “Iron Gland”. The voice in the song was provided by Tom Araya, bassist and vocalist for Slayer.

songs.full_title: So Far Under by Alice in Chains
songs.title: So Far Under

description.plain:
“So Far Under” is about that awful feeling when you find yourself outnumbered, surrounded and completely up against it and there seems little chance you can do anything about it. The lyrics were written by Alice In Chains' co-lead vocalist and rhythm guitarist William DuVall, and were inspired by personal circumstances, as well as events in the wider world. However, DuVall explained the song is not as defeatist as it may seem on first impressions.

“The lyric is a cold, hard assessment of a difficult situation but the music has a message all its own,” he said. “There’s still room to flip the script.”

songs.full_title: Last of My Kind by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Last of My Kind

description.plain:
The third track on Alice in Chains’s 2009 album Black Gives Way to Blue. “Last Of My Kind” is the first song on the album where new guitarist/vocalist William Duvall has a co-writing credit (with the other writer being longtime guitarist/vocalist Jerry Cantrell) and is the only song on the album where he sings lead all the way through.

The meaning of the song is vague. It could be about the band being the last of the old Seattle grunge bands from the 90s still playing what they play, or it could be about being rejected from a church or other institution and feeling like an outcast.

songs.full_title: All Secrets Known by Alice in Chains
songs.title: All Secrets Known

description.plain:
This was the first song on the first album Alice in Chains released after frontman Layne Staley’s death from heroin overdose in 2002. Right out of the gate, the band is basically responding to the thoughts that fans and critics were having at the time. That is, how could Alice in Chains possibly make new music worth listening to without the iconic and inimitable voice of Layne Staley?

The band lays it all out on the table here, acknowledging the hardship of finally moving on while also recognizing they will never be quite the same going forward.

songs.full_title: A Looking in View by Alice in Chains
songs.title: A Looking in View

description.plain:
“The song basically speaks to any number of things that keep you balled up inside. A cell of our own making with an unlocked door that we choose to remain in. Focusing our attention inward instead of reaching out to a much larger world. I think this is common to us all. It’s funny how hard we fight to hang on to a bone we can’t pull through a hole in the fence, or how difficult it is to put down the bag of bricks and move on”  Jerry Cantrell

The song also could be about Layne during his final reclusive years, in which he would reject his friends offers of help and treatment.

I am the child that lives and cries in a corner
Dies in a corner
Alone inside your mind ”
- Meaning he knows that the other person wants him to suffer for what he did, and cry or “die in a corner” so to speak. And be alone forever. Also, he admits to being imperfect (which shows he hurt the other person in some way in the past)

body.plain:
think this song is about 2 people who were once in a relationship, but are now afraid to speak to each other. Or afraid of what the other person thinks about them.

“ You tried to kill me off
Surprised I remain
A scale tips impossible
Afraid of my own name ”
- Meaning the person is worried that the other person hates them for something they did in the past, and is afraid of even hearing his own name spoken.

“ And I always paid attention to all the lines you crossed
Forgive this imperfection it shows and know
I am the child that lives and cries in a corner
Dies in a corner
Alone inside your mind ”
- Meaning he knows that the other person wants him to suffer for what he did, and cry or “die in a corner” so to speak. And be alone forever. Also, he admits to being imperfect (which shows he hurt the other person in some way in the past)

songs.full_title: Black Gives Way to Blue (Piano Mix) by Alice in Chains
songs.title: Black Gives Way to Blue (Piano Mix)
songs.title_with_featured: Black Gives Way to Blue (Piano Mix)

description.plain:
An alternate mix of the album’s title track, “Black Gives Way To Blue”, featuring Elton John’s wonderful piano work throughout the entirety of the song, as opposed to the original mix, where his playing comes in during the break after the first chorus.

This mix was exclusive to the iTunes edition of the album.

The acoustic guitars are noticeably more prominent in this mix as well, and Cantrell’s lead guitar is pushed farther to the back, in favour of showing off the vocal and piano performances.
